title: What Do Termites Look Like? How Tell Them Apart from Other Insects

steps.title: Tube-like body with 2 straight antennae
steps.content: Tube-like body with 2 straight antennae All termites have 2 straight, beaded antennae that may droop. They also have uniform, tube-like bodies that do not cinch in near the waist. [1] X Research source Unlike termites, ants have a narrow constriction at the top of their abdomen, which looks like a cinched waist. Their antennae are relatively smooth and bend at a ninety-degree angle. [2] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source

steps.title: ¼ to ½ inch long
steps.content: ¼ to ½ inch long Worker termites are the most common type of termite, and they’re between ⅛ to ⅜ an inch long. Soldier termites are slightly bigger than workers because they have large mandibles, or protruding jaws to defend the colony against invaders. Reproductive termites (also called alates or flying termites ) range from ½ to 1 inch long. [3] X Research source Each termite colony has different castes, or functional roles within the group. The caste system is divided into reproductive, soldier, and worker termites, and each caste has a distinctive size and look. [4] X Research source If possible, catch a termite in a mason jar so you can inspect it closely. Pick up the termite by gently clasping it between your thumb and forefinger, or by trapping it between a jar and a piece of paper. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Cream, pale red, light brown, or black in color
steps.content: Cream, pale red, light brown, or black in color Depending on the type of termite you find, it can be pale or dark. Worker termites are cream-colored and have a soft, transparent exoskeleton. Soldier termites are usually white, pale red, or light brown in color. Reproductive termites tend to be dark brown or black. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Four identical wings (for reproductives)
steps.content: Four identical wings (for reproductives) Reproductive termites have 4 wings that are roughly the same size and are translucent in color. [7] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source When folded back, the wings look like a single opaque wing that’s about twice as long as the termite’s body. [8] X Research source Worker and soldier termites do not have wings. Unlike termites, ants have 4 wings that are tinted brown, and their front wings are longer than their hind wings. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Wood damage
steps.content: Wood damage If you suspect you have an infestation in your home, tap on your walls with the head of a screwdriver. [10] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source Hollow-sounding wood could mean you have an infestation. According to Bloom, “termites are often found below or at grade areas of a structure where moisture is present.” So, inspect the base of your wall near the soil line and look for any entryways in your floor. [11] X Research source Sagging floors, peeling paint, and dark or blistered areas on wood paneling are also signs of an infestation. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Swarming termites
steps.content: Swarming termites If you find a reproductive termite in your home, there’s a high chance that you have an infestation. [13] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source Reproductives are the colony members responsible for mating, and once they find a place to lay their eggs, they’ll settle down and start building their nest. While they do not cause structural damage themselves, they do form colonies of worker termites that feed on wood and may attack your home. [14] X Research source Swarming (when termites reproduce and form new colonies) usually occurs in “late spring and early fall,” according to Break. It tends to happen in the daytime, especially on warm days after a storm. After reproductive termites mate, they lose their wings. If you see piles of silvery, membranous wings that are about ¼ of an inch long, it could be a sign of an infestation. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Termite droppings
steps.content: Termite droppings Termites feed on wood, then produce hard fecal pellets that have small dimples or ridges. The pellets are about 1/25 of an inch long, and they often show up in piles near walls or any areas where the termites have built a colony. [16] X Research source Keep in mind that some termites use their droppings as construction material for tunnels. If you have subterranean termites, for example, you might not notice droppings in your home. [17] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source

steps.title: Mud tubes
steps.content: Mud tubes Some termites build mud tubes on foundation walls or in cracks. [18] X Research source They’re made out of soil, saliva, and droppings, and are used to protect the colony from sunlight and predators. [19] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source If you see one, Break advises to “dig around the area with your hands” to see if there are termites inside. Common areas for mud tubes include where the sill plate joins your foundation wall, where support beams meet your flooring, and behind baseboards. These tubes are usually the thickness of a pencil. [20] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source

steps.title: Clicking noises in your walls
steps.content: Clicking noises in your walls Termites are usually silent, but soldiers can bang their head against the wall to recruit additional workers or attract other soldiers for defense. [21] X Research source This produces a soft clicking or rustling sound, but it may be difficult to hear in a busy household.

steps.title: Select a pest control company carefully.
steps.content: Select a pest control company carefully. According to Bloom, the top way to get rid of termites is to “contact a reputable pest control company.” A termite infestation can cause major damage to your home, so it should be treated by a professional. [22] X Research source Take time to do your research, and select a company that is licensed with the Department of Agriculture. [23] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source A company that's a member of the National Pest Management Association is also a plus. Contact 2-3 companies to get estimates. It can be costly to deal with termites, so make sure you seek out the best deal. Termites can cause damage , but do so slowly. It's okay to take some time selecting a quality company. [24] X Research source If a company uses scare tactics to pressure you into signing a contract quickly, this is probably not a good company.

steps.title: Talk over treatment options with a professional.
steps.content: Talk over treatment options with a professional. Depending on the type of termites you have, treatment will vary. They're usually treated with liquids and baits, but you can use non-chemical treatments if you want to avoid insecticides. This includes physical barriers, steel mesh, and biological control agents. [25] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source You should also discuss how much of your home you want to treat. Sometimes, a termite infestation can be cleared up with spot treatments or by treating the perimeter of your home. Other times, your entire house will need to be treated.

steps.title: Follow instructions regarding treatment.
steps.content: Follow instructions regarding treatment. When using chemicals, your pest control company will give you specific instructions. You may have to stay out of your home for a certain period of time or remove your pets. [26] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source Consult a physician if you have a medical condition that may be worsened by exposure to chemicals.

steps.title: Do not attempt to treat an infestation on your own.
steps.content: Do not attempt to treat an infestation on your own. Treating a termite infestation is complicated and requires a specific set of skills. To properly eradicate an infestation, you should not attempt to treat it yourself. Always talk to a professional exterminator to go over treatment options.

steps.title: Can termites jump?
steps.content: Can termites jump? Yes, reproductive termites (also known as alates) have wings that allow them to “jump” and fly. During the swarming season, they fly away to mate and create their own colonies. [27] X Research source

steps.title: What’s the average lifespan of a termite?
steps.content: What’s the average lifespan of a termite? While it depends on the specific type of termite, workers and soldiers typically live 1-2 years. Reproductive termites have the longest lifespan in the colony, usually surviving for 10 or more years. [28] X Research source

steps.title: How do I prevent a termite infestation?
steps.content: How do I prevent a termite infestation? Termites thrive in moist soil, so it’s important to use a concrete foundation and leave a ventilation space between the soil surface and structural wood beneath a building. After construction, keep the soil around the foundation as dry as possible through proper grading and drainage. Cover exposed wood with sealant or paint, and fix cracks, leaks, and exterior defects as soon as possible. [29] X Research source Break advises to keep “vegetation and trees at least 6 to 12 inches away from your house.” Do not pile or store wood next to your house, and perform periodic inspections to ensure termite colonies do not form. [30] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source
